qas.question: Serotonin comes from what part of the brain?
Antidepressants typically affect what chemical of the brain?
Which chemical of the brain is involved with arousal?
Norepinephrine comes from an area of the brain known as what?

context: There are dozens of other chemical neurotransmitters that are used in more limited areas of the brain, often areas dedicated to a particular function. <a1_0>Serotonin<a1_0/>, for example—the primary target of antidepressant drugs and many dietary aids—comes exclusively from a small brainstem area called the <a0_0>Raphe nuclei<a0_0/>. <a2_0>Norepinephrine<a2_0/>, which is involved in arousal, comes exclusively from a nearby small area called the <a3_0>locus coeruleus<a3_0/>. Other neurotransmitters such as acetylcholine and dopamine have multiple sources in the brain, but are not as ubiquitously distributed as glutamate and GABA.
